item.title: [Guide] How to lift/ remove model max polygon limit [Any revision]
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“the elve age, post:43, topic:329756”][quote author=t4 link=topic=426139.msg4088294#msg4088294 date=1346086369]

How is jagex now able to do this with newer models?

different engine
[/quote]I feel like still having such large poly counts in a small area would still lag even with a newer engine.[/quote]
a big difference from the new engines than the old is the fact native code is used for rendering (direct x, opengl and the like).

Read full topic

item.description:
@Java_Is_My_Bitch2 wrote:

[quote=“Miss Silabsoft, post:19, topic:329756”]you really don’t want to raise it at all, jagex did numerous tests to find the best limit.[/quote] for having 50+ character models loaded in one frame.

Read full topic
item.source: [Guide] How to lift/ remove model max polygon limit [Any revision]

item.title: [Guide] How to lift/ remove model max polygon limit [Any revision]
item.dc:creator: @djoscar djoscar
item.description:
@djoscar wrote:

[quote=“MrPotatoHead, post:33, topic:329756”]Ok you can do this [4096]=max number of triangles
the [2000]=max number of triangles with a priority, this is for when priority values are given in the file and not just using the flag value. NEED TO CHANGE THIS TO YOUR NEW VALUE

Don’t worry too much about the [1500] this is for model extents, means the maximum x,y,z value is +/-1024… sqrt(1024²*1024²) = 1448.1546 (so they use 1500 to make sure)

You changed the gzip buffer limit as well? will need to…

Now the really boring bit…
Be realistic in the new value you set, 30k polygons is stupid, the client uses fixed point arithmatic which basically means any vertices less than 4 units in distance will end up at the same point on the screen. That means the client would do lots of calculations and end up not drawing half the triangles. 8k polygons is probably more than you’ll need without having the client waste its time calculating stuff that won’t be drawn.[/quote]
I see, thanks.

How’s it going with the new datmaker, by the way?

Read full topic
item.source: [Guide] How to lift/ remove model max polygon limit [Any revision]

item.title: [Guide] How to lift/ remove model max polygon limit [Any revision]
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

Ok you can do this [4096]=max number of triangles
the [2000]=max number of triangles with a priority, this is for when priority values are given in the file and not just using the flag value. NEED TO CHANGE THIS TO YOUR NEW VALUE

Don’t worry too much about the [1500] this is for model extents, means the maximum x,y,z value is +/-1024… sqrt(1024²*1024²) = 1448.1546 (so they use 1500 to make sure)

You changed the gzip buffer limit as well? will need to…

Now the really boring bit…
Be realistic in the new value you set, 30k polygons is stupid, the client uses fixed point arithmatic which basically means any vertices less than 4 units in distance will end up at the same point on the screen. That means the client would do lots of calculations and end up not drawing half the triangles. 8k polygons is probably more than you’ll need without having the client waste its time calculating stuff that won’t be drawn.

Read full topic
item.source: [Guide] How to lift/ remove model max polygon limit [Any revision]

item.source: [Guide] How to lift/ remove model max polygon limit [Any revision]

item.title: [Guide] How to lift/ remove model max polygon limit [Any revision]
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

[quote=“djoscar, post:27, topic:329756”][quote author=CoonHunter link=topic=426139.msg3131540#msg3131540 date=1266545615]

they have a reason for limiting polygon count.

The only reason they have that limit is because they have hundreds of thousands of players online and as they said, their main aim of Runescape is for it to be available to play anywhere on any computer, therefore they don’t want to have a bigger polygon limit so players who have shitty computers would be able to play without lagg. Nothing for us to worry about, when we have like few hundred users online.

Also, I am not suggesting you to add models with 30k polygons or so lol, it was just an experiment that I done.
Normal polygon count used by games these days is anywhere up to 2k-5k, more or less. Runescape is way too low, using like max 500-1k polys per model. If they used textures with the models, then even the 500 polygons per model would look just fine, but since they use shitty coloring, it looks just awful -.-

Thanks

Runescapes 525+ HD has a texture on nearly every item/model. Also, the poly limit already is 2k, so i wouldnt increase it past that.

@Stuff you gave me to change - Your giving 508+ ints, and booleans. Please, to avoid MAJOR confusion, i would do a bit of reasearch and have each one for the correct version

High detail doesn’t have proper textures for everything. They “faked” it to look like as if everything was textured with a method called “procedural texturing”, which is literally shit. They are caring about users with lame pc’s too much, that’s why they’re using it instead of normal texturing. Of course it would take longer to load and stuff, but who cares if it takes few minutes longer than it usually does…?

@Stuff I gave you to change - I’m not giving 508+. I’m giving 508, then 317 and lastly any other revision…

Thanks

I only saw 508+ because

        aByteArray3370 = new byte[1];
        anIntArray3372 = new int[10];
        anIntArray3371 = new int[12];
        anIntArray3373 = new int[4096];
        anIntArray3368 = new int[4096];
        anIntArray3380 = new int[4096];
        aBooleanArray3381 = new boolean[4096];
        anIntArray3374 = new int[4096];
        anIntArray3382 = new int[4096];
        anIntArrayArray3379 = new int[12][4096];
        anIntArray3384 = new int[4096];
        aBooleanArray3375 = new boolean[4096];
        anIntArray3378 = new int[10];
        anIntArray3388 = new int[12];
        anIntArray3385 = new int[10];
        anIntArray3386 = new int[4096];
        anIntArray3383 = new int[4096];
        anIntArray3389 = new int[1600];
        anIntArrayArray3387 = new int[1600][512];

Are not in Class30_Sub2_Sub4_Sub6.java (Model.java) Nore does it count that high in that file. Obviously your not giving 317, possibly 377, but not 317
[/quote]
Dude, it should be dead obvious what and where to change, even for a total moron lol.
It’s not rocket science, read it again and you should understand.
I’m not giving you exact ints or anything, that was just an example of how it would look, and yes I did check it in a 317 client from Galkon. I can’t explain any clearer where to find, this is as clear as I can do…[/quote]

I had already figured it out, im just trying to convince you to clear stuff up, because i know that 80% of mopar wont know enough to look around. 60% of that 80% will just say “nope not there” and stop, thinking you must be working with a custom client. The other 40% will scroll around for 5 minutes, and about 50% of those people will actually find and figure it out.

[quote=“T3arful, post:28, topic:329756”][quote author=CoonHunter link=topic=426139.msg3131540#msg3131540 date=1266545615]
Are not in Class30_Sub2_Sub4_Sub6.java (Model.java)
[/quote]

?

private static boolean[] aBooleanArray1663 = new boolean[4096]; private static boolean[] aBooleanArray1664 = new boolean[4096]; private static int[] anIntArray1665 = new int[4096]; private static int[] anIntArray1666 = new int[4096]; private static int[] anIntArray1667 = new int[4096]; private static int[] anIntArray1668 = new int[4096]; private static int[] anIntArray1669 = new int[4096]; private static int[] anIntArray1670 = new int[4096]; [/quote]

I know, but unless he corrects things, 80% of people comming here wont get it.

Read full topic
item.source: [Guide] How to lift/ remove model max polygon limit [Any revision]

item.dc:creator: @T3arful T3arful
item.description:
@T3arful wrote:

CoonHunter:

Are not in Class30_Sub2_Sub4_Sub6.java (Model.java)

?

 private static boolean[] aBooleanArray1663 = new boolean[4096];
    private static boolean[] aBooleanArray1664 = new boolean[4096];
    private static int[] anIntArray1665 = new int[4096];
    private static int[] anIntArray1666 = new int[4096];
    private static int[] anIntArray1667 = new int[4096];
    private static int[] anIntArray1668 = new int[4096];
    private static int[] anIntArray1669 = new int[4096];
    private static int[] anIntArray1670 = new int[4096];

Read full topic

item.description:
@djoscar wrote:

[quote=“CoonHunter, post:26, topic:329756”][quote author=djoscar link=topic=426139.msg3131269#msg3131269 date=1266528146]

they have a reason for limiting polygon count.

The only reason they have that limit is because they have hundreds of thousands of players online and as they said, their main aim of Runescape is for it to be available to play anywhere on any computer, therefore they don’t want to have a bigger polygon limit so players who have shitty computers would be able to play without lagg. Nothing for us to worry about, when we have like few hundred users online.

Normal polygon count used by games these days is anywhere up to 2k-5k, more or less. Runescape is way too low, using like max 500-1k polys per model. If they used textures with the models, then even the 500 polygons per model would look just fine, but since they use shitty coloring, it looks just awful -.-

Runescapes 525+ HD has a texture on nearly every item/model. Also, the poly limit already is 2k, so i wouldnt increase it past that.

@Stuff you gave me to change - Your giving 508+ ints, and booleans. Please, to avoid MAJOR confusion, i would do a bit of reasearch and have each one for the correct version

High detail doesn’t have proper textures for everything. They “faked” it to look like as if everything was textured with a method called “procedural texturing”, which is literally shit. They are caring about users with lame pc’s too much, that’s why they’re using it instead of normal texturing. Of course it would take longer to load and stuff, but who cares if it takes few minutes longer than it usually does…?

@Stuff I gave you to change - I’m not giving 508+. I’m giving 508, then 317 and lastly any other revision…

Thanks
[/quote]

I only saw 508+ because

        aByteArray3370 = new byte[1];
        anIntArray3372 = new int[10];
        anIntArray3371 = new int[12];
        anIntArray3373 = new int[4096];
        anIntArray3368 = new int[4096];
        anIntArray3380 = new int[4096];
        aBooleanArray3381 = new boolean[4096];
        anIntArray3374 = new int[4096];
        anIntArray3382 = new int[4096];
        anIntArrayArray3379 = new int[12][4096];
        anIntArray3384 = new int[4096];
        aBooleanArray3375 = new boolean[4096];
        anIntArray3378 = new int[10];
        anIntArray3388 = new int[12];
        anIntArray3385 = new int[10];
        anIntArray3386 = new int[4096];
        anIntArray3383 = new int[4096];
        anIntArray3389 = new int[1600];
        anIntArrayArray3387 = new int[1600][512];

Are not in Class30_Sub2_Sub4_Sub6.java (Model.java) Nore does it count that high in that file. Obviously your not giving 317, possibly 377, but not 317[/quote]
Dude, it should be dead obvious what and where to change, even for a total moron lol.
It’s not rocket science, read it again and you should understand.
I’m not giving you exact ints or anything, that was just an example of how it would look, and yes I did check it in a 317 client from Galkon. I can’t explain any clearer where to find, this is as clear as I can do…
